title: Plugging in $$1.5$$ as T
text: To solve this problem, we simply have to plug in $$1.5$$ for the variable $$t$$. This will give us a value T(t) that represents our answer.

title: Plugging in $$0$$

title: Plugging in $$0$$

title: The Numerator is the Carrying Capacity
text: Since this is a logistic growth model, we know that the numerator is the carrying capacity. This means that our answer is @{numerator}

title: Plugging in $$0$$ for $$t$$
text: We must plug in $$0$$ for $$t$$, as this represents the initial population. This leaves us with $$\frac{1000}{10}$$ which simplifies to $$100$$.

title: Carrying Capacity is the Numerator
text: To find the carrying capacity, we can simply look at the numerator since it is equal to the carrying capacity. This means that the carrying capacity is @{numerator}
